key_points: A federal grand jury is considering charges against former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin for the death of George Floyd.
Chauvin is already facing state murder and manslaughter charges with his trial set to begin on March 8.
The federal investigation focuses on Chauvin and involves other officers as witnesses.
George Floyd died on May 25 after Chauvin, who is white, pressed his knee against Floyd's neck for several minutes.
Floyd's death led to nationwide protests and a reckoning on race in the United States.
Three other officers are charged with aiding and abetting Chauvin and will face trial in August.
The Justice Department under President Joe Biden is expected to place a greater emphasis on civil rights and policing policies.
Judge Merrick Garland, nominee for attorney general, pledged to combat racial discrimination in policing during his confirmation hearing.
Former Attorney General William Barr blocked a potential plea deal involving Chauvin last year.
The increased grand jury activity may be part of a broader Justice Department strategy under the new administration.
